JB, do you have more contacts than us? Could you do a little asking around?=


Failing that, perhaps this group could decide what it really wanted
and t=
hen make the changes and release a 3.8.2? I mean, it's not like
we don't ha=
ve some of the finest testing brains on the planet around
here (self _not_ =
included), not to mention some very strong opinions
(ok, I'm in this catego=
ry). Just a wild Friday afternoon kind of
thought.

On 6/3/05, J. B. Rainsb=
erger <jbrains@...> wrote:
> jason r tibbetts wrote:
> > I spent som=
e time looking at both www.junit.org and
> > junit.sourceforge.net, and it =
seems as though JUnit development has been
> > frozen in time. For example,=
 the JUnit Web page seems to have had few
> > updates since 2003. And on So=
urceForge, Erich Gamma and Kent Beck
> > responded to some GUI-related RFEs=
 with the comment that because most
> > IDEs now handle test running themse=
lves, there's no point to improving
> > JUnit's own GUI tools. Non-interfac=
e bug reports and RFEs have gone
> > unassigned unless they're of very high=
 priority (such as ones related to
> > thread safety). Is there simply no r=
eal demand for improvements, or has
> > the SourceForge bug report page bee=
n deprecated?
> 
> That's an ongoing debate in the community. I honestly be=
lieve that the
> JUnit framework is closed (in the Open/Closed Principle se=
nse), even if
> the test runners are occasionally inadequate. Since I use E=
clipse's test
> runner most of the time and Ant's the rest of the time, tha=
t's not an
> issue for me.
> 
> JUnit 4.0, complete with support for Java a=
nnotations, is in the works,
> but I don't know any more than that.
> --
> =
